Working with the Task Pane

When you click the Task tab, existing tasks display in the upper pane of the project view window. The Task menu item also becomes available on the menu bar. Double-clicking on a task shows its properties, enabling you to review or modify them.

All tasks shown in the upper pane:

  • Are attached to the folder selected from the application folder hierarchy.

  • Match the filter selected from the Filter drop-down list box. The only default task filter is Show All.

  • Match the depth specified by the All Descendants button.

Choosing a Tree or List Format

When the Tree Display button is selected on the toolbar, each task appears on the upper pane as an expandable task tree, with its subtasks as branches. The tree displays the relationship between the task and its subtasks, which must be completed before a task can be considered done. It also allows you to move and share tasks. The tree format is the default format.

Clicking an unexpanded branch of a task tree expands it; clicking it again collapses it. Double-clicking a task expands or collapses its branches. Selecting Expand All and Collapse All from the Task menu or context menu completely expands or collapses all trees.

The tree format uses special icons to indicate whether you have read the tasks and subtasks for which you are responsible. These icons indicate the following:

  • StarTeam task that has been read.

  • Unread StarTeam task.

  • StarTeam subtask that has been read.

  • Unread StarTeam subtask.

  • Microsoft Project task that has been read.

  • Unread Microsoft Project task.

  • Microsoft Project subtask that has been read.

  • Unread Microsoft Project subtask.

When the List Display button is selected on the toolbar, information in the upper pane appears in list format. No relationships among tasks and subtasks are shown. However, the list format allows you to:

  • Search tasks or subtasks for specific words or phrases.

  • See the values of specific fields as columns of data. For example, you can view the status for each task.

  • Sort the tasks or subtasks by any column header.

Using the Task Pane

From the Task pane, you can perform a variety of operations, including:

View unread items

In both tree and list format, tasks for which you are responsible but have not reviewed are shown in boldface type. The tasks in regular type are those that you have read or those for which you are not responsible.

View properties

To see the properties of a specific task, double-click it.

Review task status

In list format, you can look at the icon that appears with a task to determine its status – that is, its stage in the task lifecycle. A task may be pending, ready to start, in progress, finished, closed, or on hold.

Move tasks

In tree format, you can move a task from one application folder to another by dragging it to the new folder. You can also move tasks to other views or projects that use the same server configuration.

Share tasks

In tree format, you can share a task in one application folder with another folder by pressing Ctrl, then dragging the task to the second folder. You can also share tasks with other views or projects, as long as they use the same server configuration.

Filter data

In list format, you can rearrange fields, show different fields, use group bands, and apply queries to the data in the list. You can also save operations performed on the data as a query or filter. To perform these actions from the context menu, right-click a column header to display the menu.

Sort tasks

In list format, you can click a task column header to perform a sort based on the value in that column. The sort is usually in ascending numeric or alphanumeric order, depending on the data. To change the sort order from ascending to descending (or vice versa), click the header a second time. A triangle indicating the direction of the sort appears on the header of the primary sort column.

Default columns are:

  • Task Number: Number that the application assigned to the task when it was first submitted.

  • Task Type: Fixed units or other type of task.

  • Status: Indication of the task’s progress from submitted to rejected or completed – that is, the task lifecycle.

  • Responsibility: Name of the user responsible for completing the task.

  • Estimated Start: Date on which the task is expected to start.

  • Estimated Finish: Date on which the task is expected to finish.

  • Actual Start: Date on which the task began.

  • Actual Finish: Date on which the task was completed.

Refresh view

Press Shift + F5 to refresh the entire view (all items in all tabs as well as the application folder hierarchy). Press F5 to refresh only the Task pane. Press Ctrl + F5 to refresh the Task pane and collapse all open groups simultaneously.
